section.para: The call to handshake() (or to init()) initiates the Bayeux communication with the Bayeux server.
The Bayeux handshake performs two tasks:

listitem.para: The client and the server negotiate the type of transport to use.
Once the transport negotiates successfully, the server informs the client with the detailed timings of the requests.

section.para: As with several methods of the JavaScript CometD API, it is an asynchronous method: it returns immediately, well before the Bayeux handshake steps have completed.

note.para: Calling handshake() does not mean that you have completed the handshake with the server when handshake() returns.

section.para: The handshake might fail for several reasons:

listitem.para: The transport could not be negotiated successfully.
The server denied the handshake (for example, the authentication credentials were wrong).

It is not a good idea because there is no guarantee that the call to publish() (see ) can actually succeed in contacting the Bayeux server. Since the API is asynchronous, you have no way of knowing synchronously (that is, by having handshake() return an error code or by throwing an exception) that the handshake failed. Even if the handshake succeeds, you might still be disconnected from the Bayeux server, for example because the server crashed just after the successful handshake. Fortunately there is a way to receive notifications about the details of the Bayeux protocol message exchange: by adding listeners to special channels (called meta channels). section explains this functionality.
